Issues.Title: [HighDPI] WinForms changes the true size of controls with system DPI awareness
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 


* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
<!-- Yes / No -->

**Problem description:**
Copied from tweet thread: https://twitter.com/awakecoding/status/1389943462871633922?s=20 

 A 1920x1080 is reported as 4800x2700 with 250% DPI scaling, yet the true size of the control is still 1920x1080 (if I draw using the reported size, it is 250% larger than the real size). This means that when trying to automatically size the contents to the control size, it is always 250% too big when the system DPI scaling is set to 250%. I wouldn't mind if drawing at 250% gave the correct result, but it doesn't. I have to downscale the reported control size:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31997351/117511646-ed5e1380-af42-11eb-8637-1547e35d2a8c.png)

The odd thing is that by applying this workaround, I get a correct result even on a mixed DPI system. I can move the control between screens and it still gets the correct size by doing the inverse operation. I would have expected maybe an incorrect result on the high dpi screen?


**Minimal repro:**
a primary display in the middle with a gigantic resolution (and huge scaling factor - 250%). Add a full HD display on the left (it'll have *negative* coordinates) and another one to the right to get mixed DPI Smiling face with open mouth and cold sweat
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31997351/117511722-19799480-af43-11eb-9578-18b4c4d220b2.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[HighDPI] WinForms changes the true size of controls with system DPI awareness" (#4880)

Issues.Title: Windows Forms Designer debugging in NetCore
Issues.Body:
We could not able to perform design time debugging in NetCore Windows Forms.

We have tried to perform debugging as we perform for dot NetFramework but our source code cannot be able to debug at design time. We have followed the below steps.

1.	Set the breakpoint in our custom control constructor.
2.	Set the start-up project as “devenv.exe”.
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44424557/117460626-57d67a00-af6a-11eb-9367-e7d823ebee11.png)

3.	On running the application it shows another VisualStudio instance where we will select the project that we need to debug.
4.	Then on opening the designer and adding the custom control from the toolbox.

Expected result:
                The Breakpoint set at our custom control constructor should hit.

Observed result:
                The breakpoint hit properly in the .Net Framework project. But not for the Net core project.

**Please let us know if we need to enable any other operations to debug for the NET core project.**

Note:
We have enabled the preview feature for NetCore.
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44424557/117460590-4ee5a880-af6a-11eb-89e2-66e43746b787.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Windows Forms Designer debugging in NetCore" (#4878)

Issues.Title: Inspect can't find PropertyGrid's highlighted dropdown list in the accessibility tree
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

**.NET Core Version:**
- 6.0.100-preview.3.21202.5

**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:**
- Yes

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create an app with a PropertyGrid and button.
2. Set button as "SelectedObject" property of PropertyGrid
3. Run the app
4. Run  the Inspect
5. Expand the "AccessibleRole" dropdown list and highlight the drop-down list using the Inspect

**Actual behavior:**
The highlighted drop-down list is not displayed in the accessibility tree.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/117441815-9d7d4d80-af3e-11eb-8e62-e10c914b4a2a.png)


**Expected behavior:**
The highlighted drop-down list should be displayed in the accessibility tree.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Inspect can't find PropertyGrid's highlighted dropdown list in the accessibility tree" (#4876)

Issues.Title: Collapsed ListBox in the PropertyGrid has invalid rectangle
Issues.Body:
Fixes #3655 

## Proposed changes
- Issue is reproduced because we get the rectangle for the ListBox, whether the ListBox is expanded or not. Unfortunately, we cannot return an empty rectangle, it is replaced with a native rectangle. Therefore, we return the rectangle with the maximum offset to the invisible zone.

- Added check for "Bounds" property of ListBox items. If the ListBox is not visible (it has an "OffScreen" state), then we return an empty rectangle.

## Customer Impact
**Before fix:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/117311853-43707f80-ae8d-11eb-8d4a-b04b2e4fa115.png)

**After fix:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/117313408-8c750380-ae8e-11eb-819b-58ab6d37dfb2.png)

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->
- CTI team

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->
- Inspect

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19041.388]
- .NET Core SDK: 6.0.100-preview.3.21202.5

Issues.Title: WinForms HighDPI PerMonitorV2 ToolStrip scales wrong
Issues.Body:
**.NET Core Version:**

SDK: 5.0.202 (db7cc87d51)
Runtime: 5.0.5 (2f740adc14)

**Problem description:**

A toolstrip with items set to DisplayStyle=ImageAndText does not scale correct.

Starting the sample application provided below on my main screen with 144dpi, shows that both toolbars are of the same height:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/117140591-dafea100-adad-11eb-8aff-4eb1659a9ccb.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/117140616-e225af00-adad-11eb-824f-79bda5f7002a.png)

Now moving the window to my secondary screen with 96dpi, suddenly shows that the toolbars are now longer of the same height:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/117140820-1f8a3c80-adae-11eb-9c3b-d2d11384e057.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/117140964-48aacd00-adae-11eb-9141-bd329ef756d1.png)

In my opinion the toolbar only displaying the images has the correct size.

**Minimal repro:**
- Create new .NET-Core 5.0 WinForms app
- Set Application.SetHighDpiMode(HighDpiMode.PerMonitorV2)
- Open the forms designer for Form1
- Set AutoScaleMode = Dpi
- Create 2 ToolBars docked to the top and fill them with standard items
- Edit 1 ToolBar so that the ToolBarItems have DisplayStyle=ImageAndText

I have attached a sample project with the repro steps described above here:
[TestDpiToolStrip.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6427078/TestDpiToolStrip.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms HighDPI PerMonitorV2 ToolStrip scales wrong" (#4872)

Issues.Title: PropertyGrid: ExpandAllGridItems() on hidden control causes NullRefException on Form Dispose
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 3.1
<!-- e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info` -->

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:  No (tested with identical design)
<!-- Yes / No -->

**Problem description:**
I am using a propertygrid control on a TabControl. 
The propertygrid is located on the second TabPage, which is not the selected index when the application starts.
On creating the form, I assign a simple dataobject to the propertygrid (I picked "Color" as an example, works for all objects as far as I know).
After that, I call **ExpandAllGridItems()**.
Here is the setup, as simple as possible:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83414880/116671458-3e996080-a9a1-11eb-8273-2d8f65e00c0d.png) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83414880/116671326-1c9fde00-a9a1-11eb-88ef-ad0d3b75a465.png)

The bug :
If you close the form _before_ opening the selected "hidden tabPage" at least once, the following exception occurs (while disposing the form):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83414880/116656348-cfb20c80-a98c-11eb-9399-d181a6909fee.png)

If you select the "hidden tabPage" first and close the form afterwards (even if not in focus anymore), the form closes without any errors.

<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->
**Expected behavior:**
I would expect to get no exception. I tried the same setup in .NET Framework 4.8 with no errors. 



**Minimal repro:**
[GridControl_Dispose_bug.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6404100/GridControl_Dispose_bug.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "PropertyGrid: ExpandAllGridItems() on hidden control causes NullRefException on Form Dispose" (#4861)

Issues.Title: Port missing designer infra
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

❗ Do not squash merge!
⚠️ Review commit-by-commit


Fixes #1395
Fixes #2573
Fixes #4456
Fixes [AB#1314797](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/0bdbc590-a062-4c3f-b0f6-9383f67865ee/_workitems/edit/1314797) 


## Proposed changes

.NET codebase provides the following designers:
- [x] System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.DocumentDesigner (#122)
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.FormDocumentDesigner (#681)
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.MaskedTextBoxDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ParentControlDesigner (#122)
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ScrollableControlDesigner (#122)
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.TextBoxBaseDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ToolStripDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ToolStripDropDownDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ToolStripItemDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ToolStripMenuItemDesigner

In addition to the existing designers, the following designers are being ported and/or corrected:
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ButtonBaseDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ComboBoxDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.DocumentDesigner - functionality restored
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.GroupBoxDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.LabelDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ListBoxDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ListViewDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.PanelDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ParentControlDesigner - functionality restored
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.PictureBoxDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.RadioButtonDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.RichTextBoxDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.ScrollableControlDesigner - functionality restored
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.TextBoxDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.TreeViewDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.UpDownBaseDesigner
- [x] System.Windows.Forms.Design.UserControlDocumentDesigner

The functionality has been verified via the [awesome sample](https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/24385/Have-a-Great-DesignTime-Experience-with-a-Powerful) authored by [Paolo Foti](https://www.codeproject.com/script/Membership/View.aspx?mid=4970295).


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### After

![designer-demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/116551411-41616a80-a93b-11eb-9961-eaf666b21614.gif)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- manual
- new tests to validate necessary types are type forwarded

Issues.Title: Fix handle creation on DateTimePicker.Enabled change
Issues.Body:
This PR fixes an incorrect code in PR #4374. 

This code is using GetWindowLong and SetWindowLong on OnEnabledChanged. This could cause a handle creation before the control is displayed.

See discussion here : https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4374#discussion_r621914769

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/116522233-4bbe3d00-a918-11eb-8ef9-ddd935e6954d.png)

With this change it appears to work:

```diff
diff --git a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs b/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs
index 123873bc7..f30edc3b5 100644
--- a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs
+++ b/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs
@@ -1506,7 +1506,7 @@ namespace System.Windows.Forms
                             font,
                             clientRectWithPadding,
                             brushColor,
-                            CreateTextFormatFlags(clientRectWithPadding.Size));
+                            CreateTextFormatFlags(clientRectWithPadding.Size) | TextFormatFlags.PreserveGraphicsClipping | TextFormatFlags.PreserveGraphicsTranslateTransform);
                     }
 
                     if (Focused && ShowFocusCues && FocusLink == link)
```

Issues.Title: Disabling a focused TextBox draws TextBox wrong
Issues.Body:
**.NET Core Version:**

SDK: 5.0.202 (db7cc87d51)
Runtime: 5.0.5 (2f740adc14)

**Problem description:**

If a focused textbox is disabled while having the focus, it does not display correctly:

Here are 2 textboxes where the top one has focus:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/116527782-573f4300-a8db-11eb-9d28-ae798ec93b96.png)

The top one is now disabled, notice the weird looking border, it should look like the bottom one:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/116527560-17785b80-a8db-11eb-866c-2c332ff02235.png)


**Repro:**

I have attached a sample project showing the problem. There are 2 textboxes and a button. The button disables both textboxes. The textbox with the focus shows the problem:
[TestDisableTextBox.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6397707/TestDisableTextBox.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Disabling a focused TextBox draws TextBox wrong" (#4856)

Issues.Title: WinForms HighDPI PerMonitorV2 windows launched on secondary monitor is incorrectly scaled
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

**.NET Core Version:**

SDK: 5.0.202 (db7cc87d51)
Runtime: 5.0.5 (2f740adc14)


**Problem description:**

If the main application window is not launched on the main monitor it scales wrong, because Form.DeviceDpi has the DPI-Settings of the main monitor.

**Minimal repro:**
- Create new .NET-Core 5.0 WinForms app
- Set Application.SetHighDpiMode(HighDpiMode.PerMonitorV2)
- Open the forms designer for Form1
- Set AutoScaleMode = Dpi
- Set StartPosition = CenterScreen;

-> Build and run the project by launching it not on your primary monitor, but on a secondary monitor with different DPI from the primary monitor. You can do this for example by launching debugging from Visual Studio and quickly focusing a window on another monitor so that this monitor gets the focus.

I have attached a sample project with the repro steps described above here:
[TestDpiChanging.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6396835/TestDpiChanging.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms HighDPI PerMonitorV2 windows launched on secondary monitor is incorrectly scaled" (#4854)

Issues.Title: Adding logic for announcing of column header by Narrator
Issues.Body:
Fixes #3745


## Proposed changes
- Added "AnnounceColumnHeader" method for announcing the column header. When the user hovers over the ColumnHeader, we receive an event for redrawing. Using this event, we get data about the columns header and the shift of coordinates due to scrolling. Using the calculated coordinates, we make a HITTEST API request. From this request, we get data about the column index and announce header using the this index.

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] The Inspect tree displays information doesn't refresh timely when moving a listViewItem from default listViewGroup to another listViewGroup
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
.NET SDK 6.0.100-preview.5.21226.11

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**More info:**
1. This is a not regression issue, it also reproduced on .NET framework 4.8, .NET core 3.1 & .NET 5.0.
2. The issue is related to the fact that the Inspect tree displays information that is relevant at the time the data is received. To update the data again, the user should collapse and re-expand the item. **This is a general problem for the Inspect, not specifically related to the ListView.**

**Minimal repro:** 
[TestApp_Core.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6383007/TestApp_Core.zip)

1. Create an app with ListView which added several ListViewItems
2. Add "Test" ListViewGroup to the ListView
3. Add an event so that when you click on a special button, the second ListViewItem is moved to the "Test" ListViewGroup.
4. Run the app
5. Run the Inspect
6. Select the item2 in inspect tree
7. Press the Replace button, at this time, the item2 is moved to the "Test" group
8. Focus on item2 using mouse
9. Observe the structure of listView in inspect tree

**Actual behavior:**
The item2 is displayed in both "default" ListViewGroup and "Test" ListViewGroup.
After click refresh button in inspect, the item2 in "default" ListViewGroup disappeared.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/116208319-63a88c00-a773-11eb-900a-c2a641e4a005.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The item2 should only display in "Test" ListViewGroup.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] The Inspect tree displays information doesn't refresh timely when moving a listViewItem from default listViewGroup to another listViewGroup" (#4851)
